comments.text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:11.0a1) Gecko/20111201 Firefox/11.0a1
Build ID: 20111201031025




Expected results:

The nth% of the tab at the n% of the tabstrip should be the same after maximising/restoring (like the css background calculation).  This method will remove the annoying scroll of the tabstrip on restoring/maxing/fullscreening the window and the tabstrip should seem to stay where it was.

(0 <= n <= 1 and viewable width = tabstrip width if viewable width > tabstrip width)
tab offset + viewable width * n = viewable width * n
tab offset = (tabstrip width - viewable width) * n

n = tab offset / (tabstrip width - viewable width) if (tabstrip width - viewable width) != 0
n = 50% if (tabstrip width = viewable width)

new scroll offset on every resize = n * (tabstrip width - viewable width)

comments.text:
I'm not sure if this was fixed at some point & reintroduced in Proton or if I've never noticed this before, but this is persistently occurring to me now (Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:89.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/89.0). For example, the tab bar might look like [this (imgur)](https://imgur.com/YHCaIii) prior to fullscreening a video. After entering and exiting fullscreen, the tab bar looks like [this (imgur)](https://imgur.com/VcRaH0w). (Description: Tab bar aligns itself so the tab which was fullscreened is at the far right after exiting fullscreen; this frequently causes "recently used" tabs to be hidden (off to the right) as the tab bar is aligned to show less recently used tabs)

I'm not sure if this behaviour is (a) the behaviour described by this bug or (b) new behaviour, but at least thought it was worth leaving a comment on this report, which seems to be closely related (if not the exact same problem).
